qas.question: What are ISPs subject to monitoring by in some countries?
What is the controversial N.S.A. program used in the U.S.?

answers.text: provides for broad monitoring of Internet users traffic

qas.question: What do ISPs integrate into their network to provide information to intelligence agencies?

answers.text: a wide array of surveillance and packet sniffing equipment

qas.question: What do DCSnet in the US and SORM in Russia do?

answers.text: allowing monitoring of Internet traffic in real time

plausible_answers.text: allow law enforcement agencies to monitor some or all of the information transmitted by the ISP

qas.question: What are ISPs not legally required to do?

plausible_answers.text: broad monitoring of Internet users traffic

qas.question: What this PRISM stopped the national security agency for doing?

plausible_answers.text: a wide array of surveillance and packet sniffing equipment

qas.question: What do ISPs remove from their networks to discourage intelligence agencies?

plausible_answers.text: broad monitoring of Internet users traffic

qas.question: What do many people say violates the First Amendment?

context: Internet service providers in many countries are legally required (e.g., via Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act (CALEA) in the U.S.) to <b5_0>allow law enforcement agencies to monitor some or all of the information transmitted by the ISP<b5_0/>. Furthermore, in some countries ISPs are subject to monitoring by <a0_0>intelligence agencies<a0_0/>. In the U.S., a controversial <b7_0>National Security Agency<b7_0/> program known as <a1_0>PRISM<a1_0/> <a2_0>provides for <b6_0><b9_0>broad monitoring of Internet users traffic<b9_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/> and has raised concerns about potential violation of the privacy protections in the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution. Modern ISPs integrate <a3_0><b8_0>a wide array of surveillance and packet sniffing equipment<b8_0/><a3_0/> into their networks, which then feeds the data to law-enforcement/intelligence networks (such as DCSNet in the United States, or SORM in Russia) <a4_0>allowing monitoring of Internet traffic in real time<a4_0/>.
